subSubSection.paragraph:
Calotes bachae Hartmann, Geissler, Poyarkov, Ihlow, Galoyan, Rödder & Böhme 2013
: 252

bibRef.author: Hartmann, T. & Geissler, P. & Poyarkov, N. A. J. & Ihlow, F. & Galoyan, E. A. & Rodder, D. & W. Bohme
bibRef.title: Anew species of the genus Calotes Cuvier, 1817 (Squamata: Agamidae) from southern Vietnam
bibRef.treatmentCitation:
Hartmann, T. , Geissler, P. , Poyarkov, N. A. J. , Ihlow, F. , Galoyan, E. A. , Rödder, D. & W. Böhme ( 2013 ).
Anew species of the genus
Calotes Cuvier, 1817
( Squamata : Agamidae ) from southern Vietnam
. Zootaxa 3599 ( 3 ): 246–260 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype .
ZFMK 88935 ( adult male , Fig. 5 A-B, Clade E) from “ Vietnam , Dong Nai Province , Cat Tien National Park ( 11.6344444° N 107.456667° E ),
104 m
elevation,” collected by Peter Geissler on
May 10 th 2009
.

Original Diagnosis. Amedium-sized
Calotes
with a maximum SVL of 97 mm . It can be distinguished from all taxa of the
C. mystaceus
complex by the combination of the following characters: 1) head and body robust; 2) body scales homogeneous, relatively small, feebly keeled and arranged in regular rows; 3) 44–50 midbody scale rows; 4) upper dorsolateral scales pointing backwards and upwards; 5) two short and well separated spines, surrounded by three to four scales on either side of the upper head above the tympanum; 6) nuchal and dorsal crest continuous, composed of erected compressed scales, directed posteriorly; 7) vertebral spines and scales in males 35–42 and in females 43–46; 8) oblique fold of skin in front of fore limb insertion distinct, covered with small granular dark scales; 9) extremities and tail relatively long and slender (see comparison with
C. mystaceus
for details); 10) bluish to turquoise head and anterior body part, this coloration not well exceeding front limb insertion; 11) yellowish light stripe at upper lip reaching from below anterior corner of eye to posterior end of head; 12) no dorsolateral brownish blotches, sometimes faint medial brownish blotches across the vertebral crest.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Male coloration. The brilliant coloration of adult males is characterized by a brightly colored bluish to turquoise head, with bluish coloration continuing posteriorly to fore limb insertion. There is a relatively faded light (bright yellowish, when under acute distress, a character typical for
C. bachae
only) stripe at the upper lip crossing the tympanum from beneath the eye to end of head. Gular pouch colored in darker blue, interscale skin black. Atriangular to crescent-shaped patch of small black scales is present in front of shoulder. Very faint brownish blotches extending mid-dorsally over the vertebral crest, from above fore limb insertion on to tail; posterior to fore limb insertion brownish orange in color on trunk and tail; hind limb in a slightly darker brown; venter cream.

Distribution.
Calotes bachae
is known from southern Vietnam, with two specimens reported from the Vietnam-China border in northern Vietnam, and from eastern Cambodia ( Fig. 1 ).

Ecology.
Calotes bachae
is a diurnal, semi-arboreal lizard, often observed climbing on tree trunks at a height of 5–10 meters above the ground. The species mainly inhabits dipterocarp lowland forests and cultural landscapes up to 700 m a.s.l. The species seems to be quite heliophilic, preferring more open habitats without closed canopies ( Hartmann et al. 2013 ), but was also observed in dense tropical monsoon forests with closed canopy, in open gallery forest, and anthropogenic habitats like roadsides within the forest or open park landscapes within the headquarters of the park. In these anthropogenic habitats
C. bachae
occurs in syntopy with
Calotes versicolor
( Hartmann et al. 2013 ). According to Hartmann et al. (2013)
C. bachae
feeds onnumerous arthropods including Formicidae , Coleoptera , Orthoptera , and Myriapoda. Males acquire their breeding coloration at the end of February, while gravid females have been found mid-April and egg-laying of a clutch of five eggs was observed in April and May. Juveniles hatched after 56 days while incubated at 22 to 25° Cin captivity.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. The Bayesian consensus tree basedon 988 bp of mitochondrial DNA (12S rRNA and COI) shows six distinctlineages within
Calotes mystaceus
. Node support in terms of Bayesian posterior probabilities is indicated by circles at nodes (nodes with a BPP ≥ 0.90 are white, BPP ≥ 0.95 are grey, BPP ≥ 0.99 are black, values <0.90 arenot marked). Outgroup (
Calotes versicolor
) notshown for clarity. Numbers in parentheses behind taxa refer to localities mapped in Fig. 1.
Table 2. Description of the morphological characters and respective abbreviations used in this study.

tr.td: Distance from juncture of 3rd and 4th digits to distalmost extent (outer/distalmost surface of claw) of 4th finger.
Distance from juncture of 3rd and 4th digits to distal end of 4th digit on hindfoot.
Length of tibia from knee to heel.
Distance from anterior edge of tympanum to posterior of orbit (not pupil opening).
Distance from proximal end of forefoot to tip of fourth digit.
Dorsoventral distance from top of head to underside of jaw at transverse plane intersecting angle of jaws.
Distance from anterior edge of tympanum to tip of snout.
Distance from left to right outer edge of temporal or jaw muscles at their widest point without com- pression of soft tissue.
Distance from proximal end (heel) of hindfoot to distalmost surface of fourth toe.
Transverse distance between anterodorsal corners of left and right orbits.
Distance from left to right outer edge of jaw angles; this measurement excludes jaw musculature broadening of head.
Distance from elbow to distal end of wrist, or just before underside of forefoot.
Distance from anterior edge of orbit to posterior edge of naris.
Distance from anterior edge of orbit to tip of snout (rostral scale).
Distance from anterior of forelimb, or shoulder, to tip of snout.
Internasal or internarial distance; transverse distance between left and right nares.
Distance from dorsal to ventral surface of tail base measured just posterior to vent.
Distance from vent to distal end of tail; noting completeness or regeneration of tail.
Distance from left to right side of tail base just posterior to vent.
Body length or axilla-groin length of others; distance between posterior edge of forelimb insertion (axilla) to anterior edge of hindlimb insertion (inguen).
Distance from anterior insertion of forelimb, or shoulder, to elbow.
Distance from anterior edge of hindlimb insertion to knee.

Number of 4th digit lamellae; from 1st lamella at digits’ cleft that is wider than deep and touches dorsal digital scale (on at least one side) to most distal lamella; fragmented proximal scales are excluded.
Number of elongate scales along ‘dorsolateral snout ridge’ from above posterodorsal corner of nasal scale to and including posteriormost supraciliary scale.
Number of scales found along dorsal edge of eyelid.
Number of scales longitudinally on midline between interparietal and rostral scale.
Number of scales in transverse line between posteriormost left and right supraciliary scales, just anterior of interparietal.
Posterior end defined by posteriormost enlarged scales that touches with Suplab at rear corner of mouth.
Number of scale rows around trunk at midbody.
Number of scales on line transversally between left and right nasal scales (single scale surrounding naris).
Posterior end defined by posteriormost enlarged scales that touches Inflab at rear corner of mouth.
Number of middorsal scales (spines or not), beginning with first enlarged spine-like scale on nape to above vent.

complex. Values are given are as mean ± standard deviation and minimum – maximum. Characters marked with an asterisk were significantly different between species in the AN(C)OVA.
